awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Measuring the Composition and Structure of Rocky Extrasolar Bodies
awd_abstract_narration:
White dwarf stars collected leftover rocky material from planetary systems that orbited their host stars until the stars reached their end of life and caused their planets to break apart.  These "polluted" white dwarf stars can be studied using telescopes that measure their light broken down into different wavelengths. The signatures of different chemical elements appear at different wavelengths.  The chemical elements found telescopically give information about the bulk chemical composition of rocky material in those disintegrating planets.  The types of rocks present in the planets can be reconstructed from the bulk chemical composition.  The scientists propose studies that will use spectral observations to find more polluted white dwarf stars and assess the water and rocky content of the planetary bodies that orbited the white dwarf stars, looking for signs of earth-like plate tectonics in the planetary bodies, and studying pathways for material to travel from the planetary bodies to the host stars.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of the composition of planets orbiting other stars.  The investigators will include students who participate in the UC San Diego STARS program and other institutional initiatives aimed at underrepresented groups in their research efforts.


The investigators will continue spectroscopic observations of candidate white dwarf stars to identify those that are most heavily polluted.  Estimates of the water content for all parent bodies polluting white dwarfs will be made in combination with an assessment of the water content in white dwarfs being polluted by substantial quantities of hydrogen. From a sample of nearly 100 white dwarfs, they will estimate the occurrence rate for water-rich rocky bodies in other planetary systems.  For the subset of white dwarf stars that are being polluted by rocky crust and mantle material, they will conduct a deep search for the chemical signature of plate tectonics. Detections or deep limits on Ba and Sr will inform the possibility of plate tectonics for massive differentiated rocky bodies outside the Solar System.  Dynamical simulations will examine the ability of collisional processes to strip massive differentiated rocky bodies of their outermost crust and mantle layers, and then track this ejecta and the body it originated from to explore how white dwarfs get polluted by material from specific regions of a rocky body.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Stars that are less massive than around eight times the mass of the Sun will end their lives a White Dwarfs, which are low luminosity and small objects that are no longer supporting fusion reactions. The high gravity at their surfaces result in separation of elements in their atmospheres so that only Hydrogen or Helium dominate their spectra. But a large fraction of of all observed White Dwarfs have some pollution in their atmospheres, and the abundance of materials observed typically look similar to that found in rocky planetesimals from our Solar System. Their atmospheres are thought to evolve rapidly enough to sequester polluting materials into their interior quickly, so the observed materials are likely relatively recent and not some signature from their distant past.


Thus, it has long been thought that many White Dwarfs are experiencing regular pollution from in-falling asteroid-like bodies. Using the Solar System as a rough model for a planetary system structure the source of asteroids would be a "belt", like an asteroid belt or the Kuiper Belt. The reason they are destabilized and caused to crash into the White Dwarf is the changing dynamical structure of the planetary system as the central body loses significant mass and evolves into a White Dwarf - a process that changes orbital periods of everything in the system.


Recent observations have suggested that some White Dwarfs might be accreting something larger than typical asteroids, possibly large icy moons like many of the moons found orbiting, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. This is interesting because their are significantly fewer large icy moons in the Solar System then there are asteroids, but there is a lot more mass in the moons than in all the asteroids combined. Similarly, there are many pathways to dynamically destabilize asteroids from an asteroid belt, but liberating moons from host planets requires planets whose orbits have been completely destabilized and are having close encounters with each other.

The work done here specifically modeled the dynamical pathways for White Dwarfs to accrete asteroids or moons and tabulated the frequency for accretion events for each. The accretion efficiency is only half of the story, as the longevity of observable accretion of the materials, due to their vastly different masses, plays a role. The combined model of accretion efficiency and observability suggests that only about 1-2% of all observed polluted White Dwarfs are being polluted by moons. The rest should be caused by a steady contribution of discrete asteroids.

This work is important because it gives us insight into the composition of otherwise impossible to study bodies. Planets have been observed around other stars and their sizes and masses measured in many cases. But composition is much harder, or impossible, to constrain. Here, the White Dwarf has likely shredded the accreted body and its insides are spread out through its atmosphere allowing us to count up all of its elements. Its an actual window into the composition of asteroids and moons. Now, we have clarified that moons really can be accreted and are likely some of the objects that are being observed. Further study of them will better help us understand how planets form around other stars.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2023
Modified by: Kevin Walsh
